Description: Egyptian terracotta model of sword hilt. A fragmentary hilt of a model sword, with a ribbed handle terminating in a stud and, on each side, the head of a panther; the swell to the guard survives on one side, the rest is broken away: from its size it is probable that only the hilt was represented, not the whole sword. Although both animal heads are modelled in the round, only the front of the hilt is ribbed, the back being largely plain. Hollow, from two-piece mould. Orange-brown Nile silt with a reddish core and abundant fine gold mica and white inclusions (<1.5mm).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), Site 95 (Petrie), the terracotta workshop, at the eastern edge of the town
Curator's comments: Locally produced at Site 95 terracotta workshop noted in 1885 at the eastern edge of the city. BM1886,0401.1444, 1886,0401.1451-2, 1886,0401.1537-40, 1886,0401.1574 and 1888,0601.108 were found together at a terracottas workshop (Petrie 1886: 45). Petrie dates this workshop to about the end of the 1st century AD, Bailey 3rd to 2nd century BC. Parallel found in the Fayum, now in Cairo Museum (TR6/3/36/1=SR5/1134).
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C628)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DF.03) (Phase 1)
Condition: One of the panther heads is damaged.
